channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Python and Perl: Better Together! Perl/Python role in London
item.description: We’ve got a role open for a Senior Developer skilled in both Perl and Python. Where better for a multi-talented developer like you than an organization at apex of their field? These premium native advertising gurus understand corporate, tech, financial services, and lifestyle technology. You’ll use server-side code, client-side code, databases, and websites to develop their software platform.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: We’re looking for a junior or intermediate Perl developer interested in cross-training Perl to Node. Our client embraces flexibility, and their ideal candidate will, too. Perl may be your core competency, but if you’re invested in cross-training to Node, you may be the full package that this client wants on their team.This role is remote-friendly for those located within the UK.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. Applicants, bring your “A” game: they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer.

item.title: Good (Perl) Humans Wanted. Remote Perl role in USA
item.description: Working with first responders, educators, manufacturers, and engineers, our client is the leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions. With global reach, this company prides themselves on delivering intelligent software solutions that empower users. To help them keep doing that, they’re looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Are you at the head of the pack? Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia (or remote)
item.description: Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia. With offices in Malta or Dubai, these countries are also options. Not located in one of these three spots? We still want to hear from you, and so does our client. Strong leaders aren’t tied to a geographic location, so if you’re eager to dive into this exciting challenge, send us your CV today and tell us why!

item.title: PWC 162 › Wheatstone–Playfair Cipher
item.description: Clean and compact solution to the task Wheatstone–Playfair Cipher. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC 162 › ISBN-13
item.description: Cool use of pairmap function of List::Util. Thanks for the introduction.

item.title: Playing Fair with ISBNs
item.description: Roger's solution to the task Wheatstone-Playfair is multiple languages is the highlight for me. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Checksums and early encryption
item.description: Short and sweet blog sharing the details of the contributions. Keep it up great work.

item.description: Luis one-liner in Perl is really cool as always. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 162: ISBN-13 and Wheatstone-Playfair
item.description: Nice hack in Perl and Raku to solve the ISBN-13 task. Thanks for your contribution.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 162
item.description: I loved decoding compact solution every week. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: PWC162 - Wheatstone-Playfair
item.description: Comparison of Perl and Raku solution is fun. Plenty to learn from. Thank you.

item.title: PWC162 - ISBN-13
item.description: Compact solution in Perl and Raku, loved the hack. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Play Fair and By The Book
item.description: I always enjoy how Dave plays with the week number. I really want to know where he gets the idea.

item.title: Fair Play with Your Nose to the Grindstone
item.description: Colin made the task so simple and easy to follow. Thanks for your contributions as always.

item.title: Magic Spell Books, or 13 Revisited
item.description: Thanks for yet another engaging blog. Plenty to learn every week from your blog. Keep it up great work.

item.description: Nice blog about the use of Julia to solve the weekly challenge. Thank you for sharing.

item.title: Thirteen Wheatstones
item.description: A thorough analysis and discussion of the task Wheatstone-Playfair, you don't want to miss it. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 162
item.description: Straight forward solution to the task ISBN-13 in Perl. Thank you for your contribution.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 162
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "ISBN-13" and "Wheatstone-Playfair" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 163
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Sum Bitwise Operator" and "Summations". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: QRate - complete program
item.description: finally we got the complete program. I would recommend you checkout earlier post first.

item.title: #562 - Perl Conference
item.description:
Hi there,

I wish all the readers of the weekly newsletter, a very Happy Idd. We are celebrating Idd today in England and luckily it is a Bank Holiday as well.

I have seen Facebook post about the upcoming The Perl and Raku Conference 2022, Houston, TX. With this, I kept wondering why not have London Perl Workshop 2022 too? Being member of the LPW organizing team, I discussed it with fellow member, Julien. Good news is he seems positive about it as well. I don't know whether we have enough time to kickstart the process. Just hoping we get the opportunity to organize the conference. It has been a long time since we last had the gatherings in London. We had German Perl Workshop organized successfully only recently. Although I didn't see a single event report published by attending members unfortunately. I remember last time when I attended the German Perl Workshop, there were plenty of post event reports published as per the tradition.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
